snippet: Money for the primary training program for dislocated workers is 18 percent lower than it was in 2006, even though there are six million more people looking for work now.
abstract: Work force centers across the country that assist the unemployed are being asked to do more with less as federal funds dwindle for job training and related services; federal money for the primary training program for dislocated workers is 18 percent lower than it was in 2006; funds used to provide basic job search services, like guidance on resumes and coaching for interviews, have fallen by 13 percent; such cuts in funds for training have passed with little debate and little notice.
lead_paragraph: Money for the primary training program for dislocated workers is 18 percent lower than it was in 2006, even though there are six million more people looking for work now.

headline.seo: Federal Funds to Train Jobless Are Drying Up
headline.main: Federal Funds to Train the Jobless Are Drying Up
headline.print_headline: Funds to Train Jobless in U.S. Are Drying Up
